From the above it seems that this service is only available to non-residents.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly, and residency itself is defined in Article 217—individuals need to live there at least 183 days in a 6-month period. If not, they're treated as non-residents.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Article 217 of the Tax Code identifies that residents are those individuals permanently residing in Kazakhstan (for at least 183 calendar days in any consecutive 12-month period ending in the current tax period).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But then there's the issue of foreign nationals who are residents—they might not be eligible for that certificate, which feels like an oversight.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And it gets trickier with double tax treaties. Kazakhstan has them with only 63 countries, so what about residents from countries without a treaty?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it gets trickier with double tax treaties. Kazakhstan has them with only sixty three countries, so what about residents from countries without a treaty?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On top of that, Kazakhstan only has double tax treaties with 53 countries.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Plus, some countries, like Ireland, stop recognizing their own nationals as tax residents if they work abroad. So proving residency isn't always easy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Plus, some countries, like Ireland, stop recognizing their own nationals as tax residents if they work abroad. So proving residency isn't always easy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Quite often, countries, such as France, stop recognising their nationals as tax residents if they leave to work abroad.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's the practical side—local tax authorities used to issue reconciliation acts, but that was abolished in 2019. Now they use personal account statements, but not all offices issue hard copies.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's the practical side-local tax authorities used to issue reconciliation acts, but that was abolished in twenty nineteen. Now they use personal account statements, but not all offices issue hard copies.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This service was abolished in 2017 and has been replaced by personal account statements of budget settlements and social payments, which are issued and stamped by local tax authorities, if applied for.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which means they might not be certified, right? And we see inconsistencies—some SRD offices focus on general residency, others demand specific certificates.

dialogue_turns.text: So when filling out tax returns, like form 340, you really have to rely on the Tax Code definitions, because the on-the-ground practice isn't uniform.
